content: <metadata>   <idinfo>     <citation>       <citeinfo>         <origin>Office of Emergency Management</origin>         <pubdate>20140403</pubdate>         <title>Warning Siren Locations</title>         <geoform>vector digital data</geoform>       </citeinfo>     </citation>     <descript>       <abstract>The Office of Emergency Management's warning siren dataset. This coverage contains the locations and attribute data for all warning sirens within the City and County of Denver. Sirens are placed to provide uniform coverage throughout the City and County of Denver, including DIA. The vendor, Federal Signal, developed computer models that took into account topography, atmospheric conditions, structures, and other factors to determine the optimal placement of the sirens. Once the general area was determined; field work finalized suitable areas for exact siren placement. The intent was to avoid obstruction by buildings, locations where the solar panels are blocked by trees, and also to avoid locations such as the front yard of a residential property.</abstract>       <purpose>To show spatially the locations of warning sirens within the City and County of Denver.</purpose>       <supplinf>During 2012-2013 all old sirens were either replaced or upgraded with new sirens (FS 2001-130 model).  The last of the old sirens was actually removed during the week of July 21, 2013.  Siren's rated effective range is 6400ft at 70db.  However, that's a theoretical number derived from laboratory testing, not necessarily what you get in a real outdoor, urban environment.  See this link for spec sheet: http://www.alertnotification.com/sites/ans/files/downloads/ANS300-2001-130-1012cs.pdf  </supplinf>     </descript>     <status>       <progress>Complete</progress>       <update>As needed</update>     </status>     <spdom>       <bounding>         <westbc>-105.094540</westbc>         <eastbc>-104.657108</eastbc>         <northbc>39.891382</northbc>         <southbc>39.617961</southbc>       </bounding>     </spdom>     <keywords>       <theme>         <themekt>None</themekt>         <themekey>emergency</themekey>       </theme>       <theme>         <themekt>ISO 19115 Topic Categories</themekt>         <themekey>location</themekey>         <themekey>structure</themekey>       </theme>       <place>         <placekt>None</placekt>         <placekey>Denver</placekey>         <placekey>Denver County</placekey>         <placekey>Colorado</placekey>         <placekey>USA</placekey>       </place>     </keywords>     <accconst>None</accconst>     <useconst>ACCESS CONSTRAINTS:   None. Data or information provided by the City and County of Denver shall be used and relied upon only at the user's sole risk, and the user agrees to indemnify and hold harmless the City and County of Denver, its officials, officers and employees from any liability arising out of the use of the data/information provided.   NOT FOR ENGINEERING PURPOSES</useconst>     <datacred>Office of Emergency Management</datacred>     <secinfo>       <secsys>AVAILABLE</secsys>       <secclass>Unclassified</secclass>       <sechandl>Available to the public and accessible through Denver\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Open Data Catalog, http://data.denvergov.org/</sechandl>     </secinfo>     <native>Microsoft Windows Server 2008 R2 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; ESRI ArcGIS 10.0.5.4400</native>   </idinfo>   <dataqual />   <spdoinfo>     <direct>Vector</direct>     <ptvctinf>       <sdtsterm>         <sdtstype>Entity point</sdtstype>         <ptvctcnt>86</ptvctcnt>       </sdtsterm>     </ptvctinf>   </spdoinfo>   <spref>     <horizsys>       <geograph>         <latres>8.9831528411952133e-009</latres>         <longres>8.9831528411952133e-009</longres>         <geogunit>Decimal Degrees</geogunit>       </geograph>       <geodetic>         <horizdn>D WGS 1984</horizdn>         <ellips>WGS 1984</ellips>         <semiaxis>6378137.0</semiaxis>         <denflat>298.257223563</denflat>       </geodetic>     </horizsys>   </spref>   <eainfo>     <detailed>       <enttyp>         <enttypl>warning_sirens</enttypl>       </enttyp>       <attr>         <attrlabl>OBJECTID</attrlabl>         <attrdef>Internal feature number.</attrdef>         <attrdefs>ESRI</attrdefs>         <attrdomv>           <udom>Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.</udom>         </attrdomv>       </attr>       <attr>         <attrlabl>SIREN_NUMBER</attrlabl>         <attrdef>Warning siren identification number.</attrdef>         <attrdefs>Office of Emergency Management</attrdefs>       </attr>       <attr>         <attrlabl>POWER_TYPE</attrlabl>         <attrdef>Battery powered, solar charged.</attrdef>         <attrdefs>Office of Emergency Management</attrdefs>       </attr>       <attr>         <attrlabl>SIREN_TYPE</attrlabl>         <attrdef>Type of warning siren - Federal Signal 2001-130</attrdef>         <attrdefs>Office of Emergency Management</attrdefs>       </attr>       <attr>         <attrlabl>GEOMETRY</attrlabl>         <attrdef>Geometry</attrdef>         <attrdefs>ESRI</attrdefs>       </attr>       <attr>         <attrlabl>GLOBALID</attrlabl>         <attrdef>A field of type UUID (Universal Unique Identifier) in which values are automatically assigned by the geodatabase when a row is created. The GlobalID field is necessary for maintaining object uniqueness across replicas. All feature classes and tables participating in one-way or two-way replication must contain the GlobalID field. This field is not editable and is automatically populated when it is added for existing data. </attrdef>         <attrdefs>ESRI</attrdefs>       </attr>       <attr>         <attrlabl>ADDRESS_ID</attrlabl>         <attrdef>Denver Address Database Street Identifier</attrdef>         <attrdefs>Denver Address Database</attrdefs>       </attr>       <attr>         <attrlabl>LOCATION</attrlabl>         <attrdef>Approximate address or intersection for the warning siren location.</attrdef>         <attrdefs>Office of Emergency Management</attrdefs>       </attr>       <attr>         <attrlabl>LOCATION_NAME</attrlabl>         <attrdef>Warning siren location - where mounted.</attrdef>         <attrdefs>Office of Emergency Management</attrdefs>       </attr>       <attr>         <attrlabl>LATITUDE</attrlabl>         <attrdef>Even though geographic coordinates are angular units, ArcSDE stores and treats them as if they are planar. In this case, longitude values are considered the x-coordinate, while latitude values are the y-coordinate.</attrdef>         <attrdefs>Office of Emergency Management</attrdefs>       </attr>       <attr>         <attrlabl>LONGITUDE</attrlabl>         <attrdef>Even though geographic coordinates are angular units, ArcSDE stores and treats them as if they are planar. In this case, longitude values are considered the x-coordinate, while latitude values are the y-coordinate.</attrdef>         <attrdefs>Office of Emergency Management</attrdefs>       </attr>     </detailed>   </eainfo>   <distinfo>     <distrib>       <cntinfo>         <cntorgp>           <cntorg>City and County of Denver, Technology Services / Enterprise Data Management</cntorg>         </cntorgp>         <cntaddr>           <addrtype>unknown</addrtype>           <address>201 W Colfax Ave, Dept 301 </address>           <city>Denver</city>           <state>CO</state>           <postal>80202</postal>           <country>USA</country>         </cntaddr>         <cntfax>720-913-5237 </cntfax>         <cntemail>denvergis@denvergov.org</cntemail>         <hours>M-F 8:00am - 4:30pm (MT)</hours>       </cntinfo>     </distrib>     <distliab>See access and use constraints information.</distliab>   </distinfo>   <metainfo>     <metd>20150319</metd>     <metstdn>FGDC Content Standard for Digital Geospatial Metadata</metstdn>     <metstdv>FGDC-STD-001-1998</metstdv>     <mettc>local time</mettc>   </metainfo> </metadata>
